Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: Midway through the week, their individual sales numbers are already on pace to surpass the quota.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: The city newsletter includes a short survey about bus routes open through next week.
Story: It’s Wednesday afternoon, and my headset is glued to my ear. I’ve already closed more deals than I expected this week—my manager will be thrilled. The pressure to keep up this momentum is real; every call could mean another sale, another step closer to a bonus. I glance at my inbox between calls and spot the city newsletter. There’s a survey about the new bus routes, and I know how important public transit is for people in my neighborhood. As a citizen, I feel a responsibility to give feedback, to help shape decisions that affect us all. But the survey will take time, and every minute I’m not dialing is a minute I’m not selling. My manager expects me to stay focused, to keep my numbers high. Yet, I can’t shake the feeling that if I ignore the survey, I’m letting my community down. The phone rings again, and I hesitate, torn between my duty to my job and my duty to my city.
